tasks.title: Implement agent-driven dev Kanban workflow statuses and gate criteria
tasks.description: Adopt production-flavored workflow states (Backlog, Ready, Planning, Implementing, Review, Verification, Awaiting Human, Done, Cancelled), enforce movement gates (Definition of Ready/Done), and require stage artifacts for Planning/Review/Verification/Awaiting Human. Keep board readable with explicit handoffs and deterministic agent behavior.

discoveryQuestions: Should next-task pull from Ready only or also from Planning?
Do we need WIP limits enforced in backend or only surfaced in UI?
Should Done mean merged-only or merge-approved?
acceptanceCriteria: Board supports statuses: backlog, ready, planning, implementing, review, verification, awaiting_human, done, cancelled
Entry/exit gate rules are defined and enforced for Ready and Done
Agent movement rules require artifacts for Planning, Review, Verification, Awaiting Human
Awaiting Human requires explicit question, options, and recommended default
Workflow remains deterministic and readable with minimal columns

tasks.title: Make task statuses configurable
tasks.description: Replace hardcoded task status enum with configurable status definitions managed centrally, including allowed transitions and display metadata.

acceptanceCriteria: Status list is loaded from configuration rather than hardcoded literals
Allowed transitions are configurable
UI and backend consume same status definitions

tasks.title: Improve Kanban UX/readability and preserve page on refresh
tasks.description: Refine Kanban board layout and card presentation so columns, counts, and content remain readable across viewport sizes (especially lower height/width ratios), and implement page-level navigation persistence so refreshing on Kanban returns to Kanban (and Dashboard remains independent). Include a short design research pass and implementation plan before coding.

knownRisks: Very small viewports still rely on horizontal scrolling for many lanes
URL query persistence assumes single-view parameter ownership
changeSummary: Kanban board now renders as horizontal scroll lanes with stable lane widths
Lane headers/count chips are sticky and remain visible during lane scroll
Task card typography and spacing adjusted for better readability in dense boards
Active page state persists via URL query parameter (?view=dashboard|kanban)

notes: Full verify passed: lint, typecheck, circular, coverage, build
Kanban readability and refresh persistence implemented
Workflow skills added for deterministic stage transitions

planningArtifact.recommendedDefault: Use URL query param view=dashboard|kanban for persistence
risks: Overly wide lanes can hide content on small screens
URL sync logic can break history/back behavior if not guarded
implementationSteps: Add URL-backed view state hook for dashboard/kanban
Refactor Kanban lane container to horizontal-scroll board with stable lane min-width
Polish card visual hierarchy and metadata chips for dense multi-lane layout
Add/adjust tests for view persistence and board rendering
goals: Improve Kanban readability across constrained viewports
Prevent clipping of lane counts and controls
Preserve active page (dashboard/kanban) on refresh via URL-driven view state

tasks.title: Defect: Improve Kanban task card readability in dark mode
tasks.description: Fix low-contrast and cramped task cards in dark mode. Research modern compact information-card patterns (including icon-forward density techniques) and apply them to Kanban task cards so content is legible and scannable in constrained widths.

planningArtifact.recommendedDefault: Use icon + short label hybrid metadata row; avoid icon-only critical fields
risks: Over-compressing metadata can hide important context
Icon-only indicators may reduce clarity without labels/tooltips
implementationSteps: Research compact card patterns and dark-mode contrast guidance
Refactor card visual hierarchy (title, snippet, metadata row)
Add icons for priority/dependencies/tags where space is constrained
Tune chip and card colors for dark mode contrast
Update frontend tests for card metadata visibility
goals: Fix dark-mode contrast/readability issues in Kanban cards
Improve compact information density using icon-supported metadata
Retain scanability across narrow lane widths

changeSummary: Refactored Kanban visual styles into centralized mode tokens for maintainability
Applied explicit dark/light lane and task card palettes to eliminate gray-background/low-legibility combinations
Kept metadata compact with icon-plus-label pills and predictable contrast levels

notes: PR approved and merged to main

tasks.title: Automate task completion when PR is merged to main
tasks.description: Implement an event-driven integration so merging a task branch PR to main automatically transitions the mapped task to done in the backend task system, with audit trail and failure handling.

discoveryQuestions: Should we use GitHub webhook receiver in backend or GitHub Actions calling backend API?
What is canonical task linkage key: branch name, task id in PR title, or metadata field?
How do we secure automation endpoint authentication from GitHub?
acceptanceCriteria: When a PR linked to a task is merged to main, task status transitions to done automatically
Automation writes an auditable event with PR number and commit SHA
If update fails, failure is logged and retriable without duplicate transitions

tasks.title: Split CI verify pipeline into explicit GitHub Actions checks
tasks.description: Refactor CI so TypeScript typecheck, ESLint, unit tests, and coverage run as separate named checks in GitHub Actions, and add PR coverage status feedback so failures and coverage regressions are obvious.

goals: Split CI into explicit independently visible checks
Surface PR coverage status automatically for reviewers
Keep local and CI quality gates aligned
implementationSteps: Refactor .github/workflows/ci.yml into separate jobs for tsc, eslint, unit test, and coverage
Add a PR-only coverage comment job that reports backend/frontend and combined coverage
Update documentation to explain the new CI checks and gating behavior
Run full verify command suite before handoff
risks: Coverage comment spam if updates are not idempotent
Duplicated npm ci across jobs can increase CI runtime
Coverage aggregation may drift if report file paths change
planningArtifact.recommendedDefault: Use a single ci workflow with multiple named jobs and post one updatable PR coverage comment

discoveryQuestions: Should each check run in its own workflow file or as separate jobs in one workflow with distinct required status checks?
Do we want coverage comment updates on every push or only when base/head coverage changes?
Should coverage policy gate PR merge on absolute threshold, non-regression, or both?
acceptanceCriteria: PRs show distinct required checks for ci / tsc --noEmit, ci / eslint, ci / unit test, and ci / code coverage
Failures identify the failing quality gate without reading combined logs
Coverage result is posted to the PR with current percentage and pass/fail against policy
Workflow documentation describes each check and merge gating behavior

changeSummary: Split CI workflow into discrete named checks for typecheck, lint, unit test, coverage, circular deps, and build
Added PR coverage comment job and coverage summary extraction
Added deterministic finish-task automation script for verify->commit->push->PR->review transition
knownRisks: Coverage comment depends on coverage-summary output paths staying stable
Running split jobs increases repeated dependency install time

notes: Task transitioned to review after implementation handoff

tasks.title: Evaluate combining backlog and ready workflow statuses

discoveryQuestions: Do we still need a distinct queue for not-yet-groomed tasks if ready is removed?
How should next-task selection behave when only one pre-planning status exists?

acceptanceCriteria: Decision documented on whether backlog and ready should be merged
If merged, status model, transition rules, and UI labels are updated consistently
